title: 106_hr1994
content: The Act titled "Small Business and Financial Institutions Tax Relief Act of 1999" expands S Corporation eligible shareholders to include IRAs. The Act "Small Business and Financial Institutions Tax Relief Act of 1999" allows IRAs to be shareholders in S Corporations, with specific provisions for trusts that constitute individual retirement accounts. The Small Business and Financial Institutions Tax Relief Act of 1999 allows IRAs to be shareholders in S Corporations. The act includes provisions for the sale of stock held by a trust that constitutes an individual retirement account to the individual for whom the account is established, if the sale is pursuant to an election under section 1362(a). The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1999. SEC. 3. Excludes investment securities income from passive income test for bank S corporations. The amendment excludes certain types of income from the passive investment income definition for banks and bank holding companies. The amendment excludes specific types of income from the passive investment income definition for banks and bank holding companies. It allows certain stock and participation certificates to be held by these entities for conducting banking business. The amendment is effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 1996. SEC. 4 increases the number of eligible shareholders to 150 for small business corporations. The amendment is effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. SEC. 5 addresses the treatment of qualifying director shares. The amendment in SEC. 5 addresses the treatment of qualifying director shares in small business corporations, defining them as shares held by directors that are not considered a second class of stock. The amendment addresses the treatment of qualifying director shares in small business corporations, defining them as shares held by directors that are subject to an agreement for disposal at the same price upon termination. Distributions on these shares are included as ordinary income for the holder and deductible for the corporation. The amendment addresses the treatment of qualifying director shares in small business corporations, defining them as shares subject to an agreement for disposal at the same price upon termination. Distributions on these shares are included as ordinary income for the holder and deductible for the corporation. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 are made to ensure proper allocation of items for qualifying director shares. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1996. SEC. 6. The Treasury Secretary will adjust regulations for S corporation elections after December 31, 1996, regarding bad debt deductions to be treated as built-in losses during the period of recognizing built-in gains. SEC. 7. Banks are included in the 3-year S corporation rule for corporate preference items. SEC. 8. Expansion of S Corporation eligible shareholders to include family limited partnerships. Amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. Expansion of S Corporation eligible shareholders to include family limited partnerships. Amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. Section 1361 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow family partnerships to be shareholders in an S corporation if all partners or members are members of 1 family. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1999, allowing family partnerships to be shareholders in an S corporation if all partners or members are members of 1 family. Each partner or member shall be treated as a shareholder for purposes of subsection (b)(1)(A). The SEC. 9 allows the issuance of preferred stock. The SEC. 9 allows the issuance of qualified preferred stock that is not considered a second class of stock and does not confer shareholder status. Qualified preferred stock is defined as stock meeting specific requirements outlined in the Internal Revenue Code. The SEC. 9 allows the issuance of qualified preferred stock that is not considered a second class of stock and does not confer shareholder status. Distributions made with respect to qualified preferred stock are includible as ordinary income and deductible to the corporation as an expense. Amendments are made to sections 1361(b)(1) and 1366(a) of the Internal Revenue Code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1999 for qualified preferred stock holders. SEC. 10. CONSENT TO ELECTIONS. Section 1362(a)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to require consent from shareholders holding at least 90 percent of shares for an election. Rules for consent include joint owners and representatives consenting for their shares. The consent requirements for different types of shareholders include the personal representative for deceased individuals, parents or guardians for minors, trustees for trusts, and authorized officers for organizations. In the case of partnerships or limited liability companies, all general partners, managers, or members must consent to shares owned by the organization. This is in accordance with Section 1361 of the Internal Revenue Code. Nonconsenting shareholder stock in an S corporation is not considered a second class of stock but rather treated as C corporation stock. The shareholder's pro rata share with respect to such stock is subject to tax paid by the S corporation at the highest rate specified in the tax code. Nonconsenting shareholder stock in an S corporation is treated as C corporation stock. Distributions made with respect to nonconsenting shareholder stock are included as ordinary income for the holder and deductible as an expense for the corporation. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 are made to include subsection (h). The amendments made by this section apply to elections in taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. SEC. 11 amends Section 1361(b)(3)(A) of the Internal Revenue Code to include information returns for qualified Subchapter S subsidiaries. The amendment applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1999.
